title: Neo-Capitalism
text:
Neo-capitalism is an economic ideology which blends some elements of <a href="capitalism">capitalism</a> with other systems. The new capitalism was new compared to the capitalism in the era before <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>.
Social and economic ideology that arose in the second half of the 20th century and in which the capitalist doctrine becomes deeper, being based on <a href="technological%20revolution">technological revolution</a> and on the <a href="internationalization">internationalization</a> of the markets.
It is a term used to designate a new form of capitalism that is characterized for correcting its excesses by means of the application of measures that guard over the <a href="social%20well-being">social well-being</a>.
The important aspects include a great <a href="economic%20freedom">economic freedom</a>, attaching the <a href="private%20property">private property</a> of the industries and companies, moderated with a centralized <a href="economic%20planning">economic planning</a>, which can include that the state is an owner of some means of production.
It tries to support a balance between the <a href="economic%20growth">economic growth</a>, lower inflation, low levels of unemployment, good conditions of work, social assistance and good <a href="public%20services">public services</a>, across the <a href="Economic%20interventionism">intervention of the state in the economy</a>.
It arises in the technological companies reconstructed in the postwar period.
One of its more outstanding representatives is the <a href="Keynesian%20economics">Keynesian</a> economist <a href="Paul%20Samuelson">Paul Samuelson</a>.
